Transcription for 2090966

Llyfr yn y Llyfr yn y Criedd
By Jeff Dendle
Llyfr yn y Llyfr yn y Criedd yw'r ddau'r llyfr yn y criedd yma
a'r sgwyl i'r Llyfr yn y Criedd yma
a'i gweithio ar amser am ymlaen.
Mae'r llyfr wedi'i ddweud y stori o ddod a'i renoi
a, yn dda, y cyfrwng o'r ddau i'n Criedd yn y Criedd.
Mae'r stori yn y cyfrwng yn y cyfrwng pan oeddwn yn mynd i'r ddau,
ond mae hynny'n digwydd y pethau o blynyddoedd
ac roeddwn i'n mynd i'r recordio'r benniau pan oeddwn yn mynd i'r ddau.
Mae'r llyfr yn fwy o seriau o gyfrwng,
yn enwedig o'r stori ymlaen.
Mae'n anhygoel bod yn gwrwyddo hyn yn y cyfrwng o'r llocdau
ar gyfer ymlaen o'r cyfrwng Covid-19.
Felly mae'r llyfr yn fwy o seriau o fywyd yma
yn anhygoel i'r stori'r grwm ar hyn o bryd,
yn y cyfrwng yma a'r holl ddau ymlaen.
Mae'r ddau ymlaen yn siarad yn y cyfrwng Criedd yn ymlaen,
yn ymwneud √¢'n rhan.
Bydd yn dod at y pethau i'w ddysgu,
y cyfrwng a'r cyfrwng sydd gennym ni,
a chyfrwng ymlaen i hyn yn Ewrop Norwng,
gyda'r ffyrdd a'r cymorth sy'n cael yr llaeth yn ei ffyrdd i ni.
Mae'n gwneud i ni ddysgu rhai o'n rhan yno.
Rwy'n ddiddorol iawn i'r bobl o Criedd
am eu chyfrwng cychwyn i'r ffrindiau.
Rwy'n hefyd ddim yn gallu cymryd llyfr o'r enegau,
ymgyrch, ymgyrch a'r llyfr
gweithio i ni ymlaen ymlaen
gan fy mhob ymlaen, Stephanie.

Un o'r gweithwyr yn cymryd, un man sy'n hau'r holl hwyl a'i ddarparu os ydym wedi dod i fynd i fynd.
Roeddwn yn dweud bod ni ddim yn gwasanaethau hotel, ond byddwn yn gallu ddod yn dda i ddau i ffrindiau?
Ymddygiad ymddygiadol i ddwy ffrindiau ymddygiadol yn cael ei gwybodaeth gyda'r ffyrdd bryd.
Rwy'n gwybod, ond beth yw'r hotel ydych chi'n gwneud?

yn dda ar y balustraidd ymlaen, lle roedd yn ddod yn dda'r lles.
A bydd hynny'n gweithio i chi?

yn mynd i weld ymlaen at y cyfle newydd sydd wedi'i gael y bwyd ymlaen yn y ffrindiau.

mae'n ffrind newydd wedi'i gael y menywau i fyny,
ond roedd yn fwy o ffrindiau yn siarad.
Oedd ein ffrindiau?

Beth ydym wedi'i gwneud?
Roedd yn gweithio yn England, a ddod yn ymgwybod?
Why not stay longer if we were retired?
He was retiring the coming winter.
What hints did we have for retirement?
Well, I could hardly recommend a house on the Greek island.
He probably already lived in one.
A good lunch of seafood salads,
followed by fresh fruit and ice cream,
was followed by laze on sunbeds
and a swim in the clear deep water of the terrace.
We had found a new favourite place for relaxing days,
and in subsequent visits to the island we would often return.
3. Shopping
Living in the village allowed us to experience
a particular aspect of village life.
We had already found that local traders
plied their wares at various regular markets on the island,
and we had learnt the regular days for each town,
where the same traders would set up for the morning's business.
In our town it was on Friday,
and as well as a number of fruit and vegetable stores,
there were other businesses selling everything
from local cheeses and honey to local food.
The range was from small-holders selling vegetables from their land
to suppliers who also had shops in the towns,
so it was often rather disconcerting to go into a smart shop in the next town
to recognise a familiar face that you remembered had sold you some tea towels at an earlier market.
Still, it all made for good business,
and the vegetables and fruit were very fresh, cheap and of good quality.
4. Food
The regular markets had another advantage.
I once bought a pair of cotton jeans without trying them on.
At home there was a realisation that they were aspirational,
and did not appear to be accurately labelled for the size.
The following day we went to the next town for their market
and to track down Mr Trousers as we cushioned him,
who was happy to exchange them for a roomier size.
Needless to say, no receipt was required.
In this town,
during our first day at the house,
we were surprised one morning to hear tannoy music
moving through the narrow village streets,
followed by shouting of repeated Greek words
that sounded like the words for shoes and socks.
Sure enough, when we followed the sound up to the top of our street,
there was a pick-up van with a tannoy on the roof
and a flatbed behind it full of boxed and unboxed pairs of shoes, boots and sandals.
The van was already partly surrounded by a number of lathes
of the village, some already trying on the latest shoes,
others with wrapped purchases handing over their euros.
It was an advanced form of Greek online shopping,
with the advantage of try before you buy.
Over time we recognised the various offerings,
so we were able to buy kilos of oranges for pressing fresh orange juice,
as well as other goodies, right at the end of our street.
We were wrong-footed on one occasion when a rush to the van
after not recognising the loud spoken offering,
only to find that the sales were limited to snails and raki, the local spirit.
We resisted, whilst acknowledging that to some
this might constitute the ingredients for a good night in.
The markets in the town are also socially important,
and the bars and restaurants around the harbour near the site of the market
always enjoyed the busiest mornings of the week,
as the shoppers refreshed themselves with frapp√©s, juices and coffees,
whilst exchanging details at successful purchases.
Over the years the market moved location from one of the back streets,
one road back from the main square,
a road narrow enough to have the welcome shading by Tollpaul in screen
stretched between the stalls,
a location popular with the restaurant owners nearby.
Then some genius moved it some several hundred yards up the hill,
onto the site of the unfinished bypass road.
This was short-lived, unpopular, and at our next visit
it had moved back down the hill for a few years,
until it was moved nearer the beach on the site of the old children's playground.
It has stayed here, with the old gravel-strewn playground having been modernised
and resited onto a soft artificial play surface next to the beach promenade.
The resurfacing demonstrates some nod to modern health and safety sensibilities,
not always witnessed on the island.
Secret and scaffolding and driving discipline.
We usually drive down to the market and search for parking space,
as it's one of the busiest days in the town.
One of the best bites is a large bouquet of fresh vegetables.
Fronds of fennel, greenness, kale and celery all bundled together.
The local hard and soft cheeses are always tempting,
particularly as the sales technique involves changing the taste of the food.
The shopping is followed by an iced coffee in our favourite bar,
which will be crowded with other shoppers
before taking the pressure supplies back to the house.
Often the shopping would have to be passed inspection by the village ladies from their chairs,
who we discovered went to the market themselves, but at a much earlier time.
We had discovered this fact accidentally one evening,
after innocently replying to a question from one of the marias
whether we would be going to the market the next day.
The yes, of course, sir, can we get you anything?
The reply of no, I will come with you. Meet me outside my house at seven.
Seven o'clock? Yes, you mentioned, cala,
which seemed to indicate this was necessary so as not to miss the good stuff.
We set the alarm for about two hours before we were usually breakfast in
and called at the house for the drive down.
On route we recognised Yrgo, the church warden,
who doubled as the bell ringer in the largest of the three small churches in the village.
He stuck his arm out and I just managed to avoid maiming him by slamming the brakes on.
He opened the back door and got in the back next to Maria.
After some good mornings, Maria started some instructions to me,
which I interpreted as instructions to turn off the air conditioning.
I recognised the Greek for cold as it was accompanied by a shivering mime.
I concluded this was for Yrgo's benefit as she'd been happy until he got in.
Yrgo was wearing his summer wardrobe with a tweed jacket, v-neck jumper and collar and tie.
As it was only in the low twenties, we didn't want him to get a chill.
We asked where we should take him, the market, no, the church,
which was on the way, so it should be easy.
But a near accident almost occurred when we, our elderly hitchhiker,
opened the back door prematurely and seemed to be climbing out before I'd stopped.
No damage was done and with the way of Yrgo across the road to the church,
accompanied by honking from two motorcyclists, he totally disregarded in his ecumenical hurry.
We tried to ask Maria whether he expected to live back to the village,
but this has only met with a shrug of indifference.
On a later market visit with Maria, we learnt firsthand that these were not always seen to be return trips,
as we lost sight of Maria in the market and after a decent interval I drove up the hill,
expecting to see her, but she was not en route or at home,
so I drove back to town only to spot her sitting in the passenger seat of a neighbour's car being driven up the hill.
There was still much to learn about local customs.
The market was surprisingly busy.
In all honesty, we'd not realised it started this early.
We normally planned our weekly visit to end with Eleven's coffee.
Maria seemed to know everyone, which wasn't surprising as the customers mostly were contemporaries of hers,
but there were also a few faces we recognised as owners of the smaller restaurants and cafes,
presumably shopping before opening their businesses.
Several, unrecognised, asked why we were out so early.
Just bringing down a neighbour was my answer, which was met with a knowing smile.
This was another disadvantage.
As they were out shopping, they'd not opened their cafes or bars yet,
so we couldn't have our second morning coffee out.
At 7.30 Maria announced she had all her shopping and it was time to go home.
After driving her up the hill and arguing with her about me carrying her shopping,
an argument which I lost, we said our goodbyes,
thanking as she pressed a large chunk of wrapped cheese into my hand.
It had been quite a morning and it wasn't yet eight o'clock.
Maria went off home and to open her one-room cafe near next door,
one of the many octogenarian cafe owners on the island.
